On Thu, May 02, 2002 at 05:16:42AM -0700, Eric Heikkila wrote:
> Once again, what I've done in the past is create the
> directories and files in setUp() and removed them in
> tearDown().  Depends on how complex the files and
> directory structure needs to be, I suppose.

Been there, done that. I needed it to test file system related
functions on an embedded platform.

Made a TestSetup subclass called DirTreeTest that takes a root path
and an inputstream:

  + in setUp(), unzip the data from the inputstream at the root path
  + in tearDown(), delete everything below the root path

I use it like this:

  public class Test
  {

    public static void main (String[] args)
    {
      TestSuite suite = suite();

      DirTreeTest wrapper =
        new DirTreeTest(DIR_TREE_ROOT,
                        Test.class.getResourceAsStream(DIR_TREE_DATA),
                        suite);

      TestRunner.run(wrapper);
    }

    static TestSuite suite()
    {
      // create test suite
    }
  }

Notice how Class.getResourceAsStream() is used to get the test data.
That way, the test data can be included as a zip file inside the same
jar that contains the actual test classes. So besides the test jar, no
additional data is needed.

If people are interested, I could post the DirTreeTest code.
